item.title: Keith Lofstrom <keithl@kl-ic.com>: Re: [PLUG] PLUG business card (2)
item.description:
On 10/3/05, Keith Lofstrom  wrote:
>
> > of paper for the URL, it would be quicker to hand them a business
> > card with useful pointers and info.  Who would be interested in
> > buying some from me (at cost) if I had some printed up?
...
> > Does this interest people?

On Mon, Oct 03, 2005 at 12:02:42PM -0700, Jason R. Martin wrote:
> Sounds interesting, but what about the option of printing your own? 
> Simply creating the design and making it available on the website for
> anyone to download and print on standard sized business cards?  Seems
> cheaper for those of us likely to hand out about 5 in our lifetimes
> :-)
> 
> Jason

Of course I will open-source the card design and put it on my website. 
But at a nickel a piece, it is a lot easier to have them printed.

Can I put you down for 5 for a quarter?  :-)

Keith

item.title: "slinkymax0r" <slinkywizard@integraonline.com>: Re: [PLUG] RAID for remote filesystems
item.description:
> Does anyone know if it's possible to RAID remote filesystems? I'm thinking
> of being able to combine multiple sshfs or gmailfs filesystems into one
> mount point.

RAID is a block level or byte level technology... not a file level one. 
You could certainly mirror data between two systems, but it sounds like
you're more looking into representing multiple mount points as a single
name space.

Regards,
Max




> Thanks,
> ~M
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG@lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>

item.title: David Pool <dpool@hevanet.com>: [PLUG] Interesting article
item.description:
There's an interesting article being carried on News4Neighbors as well
as Linux Today and BlueOregon:

http://www.news4neighbors.net/article.pl?sid=05/10/03/195242

Describes the trip down to OSU's open source labs while covering a
variety of related issues from HB 2892, to the Bus Project and POSSE.

David

item.title: "Jason R. Martin" <nsxfreddy@gmail.com>: Re: [PLUG] PLUG business card
item.description:
On 10/3/05, Keith Lofstrom  wrote:
>
> Sometimes people ask about PLUG - or don't run away fast enough
> when I tell them about it :-) .   Rather than hunting down a scrap
> of paper for the URL, it would be quicker to hand them a business
> card with useful pointers and info.  Who would be interested in
> buying some from me (at cost) if I had some printed up?
>
> Two thousand color, double-sided cards from Overnightprints.com
> costs $90 or so.  I've used them a few times before.  The quality
> is good - if you proof them correctly!
>
> I was thinking about a card with a group photo of us on the
> front, partly whited out, with "PLUG" and "www.pdxlinux.org"
> overlaid in large black letters.   Perhaps someone has a large
> inflatable Tux, or perhaps we GIMP the Tux+Umbrella logo into
> the photo.
>
> On the back, a smaller print listing of the meetings when&where,
> with a disclaimer to check the website in case they change.  We've
> been fairly regular about times and venues, though Murphy says
> something will change as soon as we print cards :-/
>
> Of course, I would put the digital proofs up on the web (as pdfs)
> before I sent in the order.
>
> I can bring a digital camera Thursday, and if you doesn't want
> to appear in the photo, that's OK, you can hold the camera.
>
> Does this interest people?

Sounds interesting, but what about the option of printing your own? 
Simply creating the design and making it available on the website for
anyone to download and print on standard sized business cards?  Seems
cheaper for those of us likely to hand out about 5 in our lifetimes
:-)

Jason

item.title: Keith Lofstrom <keithl@kl-ic.com>: [PLUG] PLUG business card
item.description:
Sometimes people ask about PLUG - or don't run away fast enough
when I tell them about it :-) .   Rather than hunting down a scrap
of paper for the URL, it would be quicker to hand them a business
card with useful pointers and info.  Who would be interested in
buying some from me (at cost) if I had some printed up?

Two thousand color, double-sided cards from Overnightprints.com
costs $90 or so.  I've used them a few times before.  The quality
is good - if you proof them correctly!

I was thinking about a card with a group photo of us on the
front, partly whited out, with "PLUG" and "www.pdxlinux.org"
overlaid in large black letters.   Perhaps someone has a large
inflatable Tux, or perhaps we GIMP the Tux+Umbrella logo into
the photo.  

On the back, a smaller print listing of the meetings when&where,
with a disclaimer to check the website in case they change.  We've
been fairly regular about times and venues, though Murphy says 
something will change as soon as we print cards :-/

Of course, I would put the digital proofs up on the web (as pdfs)
before I sent in the order.

I can bring a digital camera Thursday, and if you doesn't want
to appear in the photo, that's OK, you can hold the camera.

Does this interest people?

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom          keithl@keithl.com         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

item.title: Eli Stair <eli.stair@gmail.com>: Re: [PLUG] RAID for remote filesystems
item.description:
Since your filesystem needs to be laid on TOP of a block-level device,
you can't really do what you're looking to... the closest
approximation would be using a cluster filesystem that takes into
account some underlying fabric connecting a bunch of block devices
(Lustre, PVFS, GFS, etc)...

Though it would likely be possible to hack together a bunch of network
block devices mounted locally and do this.  I'm not sure about your
sshfs or gmailfs filesystems, I'm guessing they won't enable you to do
that however.  Perhaps if you could kludge a sparse file as a block
device (cryptoloop or somesuch) accessed OVER these and mounted
locally you could do it?  If you're accessing these over commodity
internet with so many layers of abstraction, it's unlikely to be
usable or stable however :)

/eli

On 10/3/05, Matt Alexander  wrote:
> Does anyone know if it's possible to RAID remote filesystems? I'm thinking
> of being able to combine multiple sshfs or gmailfs filesystems into one
> mount point.
> Thanks,
> ~M
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG@lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>

item.title: Matt Alexander <lowbassman@gmail.com>: [PLUG] RAID for remote filesystems
item.description:
Does anyone know if it's possible to RAID remote filesystems? I'm thinking
of being able to combine multiple sshfs or gmailfs filesystems into one
mount point.
Thanks,
~M

item.title: Galen Seitz <galens@seitzassoc.com>: [PLUG] fedora core 4 and Intel wireless 2200BG constant arp traffic
item.description:
The wireless indicator on my laptop has been flashing for no apparent
reason, so I ran tcpdump.  It seems to be sending out arp requests every
2 seconds or so.  My network only uses 192.168.1.x.  My google searches for
192.168.30.32 have only brought up references to Cisco equipment.  Any
ideas what might be generating this traffic?

09:52:23.745963 arp who-has 192.168.30.32 (Broadcast) tell 192.168.30.32
09:52:25.849095 arp who-has 192.168.30.32 (Broadcast) tell 192.168.30.32
09:52:27.883470 arp who-has 192.168.30.32 (Broadcast) tell 192.168.30.32
09:52:29.936135 arp who-has 192.168.30.32 (Broadcast) tell 192.168.30.32
09:52:32.010254 arp who-has 192.168.30.32 (Broadcast) tell 192.168.30.32
09:52:34.063133 arp who-has 192.168.30.32 (Broadcast) tell 192.168.30.32

The laptop is a Thinkpad X40 with an Intel 2200BG wireless card,
and Fedora core 4, and the kernel version is 2.6.12.1456_FC4.

thanks,
galen

item.title: Paul Heinlein <heinlein@madboa.com>: Re: [PLUG] rpm spec file macro expansion
item.description:
On Sun, 2 Oct 2005, Galen Seitz wrote:

> I'm trying to build some cross tools for the AVR microcontrollers, 
> and I need to work around an issue with file collisions.  When I 
> build cross versions of binutils, gcc, and gdb, the info files that 
> get created have the same name and path as the corresponding files 
> for the native host tools.  In order to eliminate the conflict, I'd 
> like to do something like the following in my spec file:
>
> %define _infodir %{_infodir}/avr

Generally, I'd just a) specify your longer path throughout the spec 
file or b) define _infodir with a macro further up the chain or with a 
full pathname

a) When building and installing, specify --infodir=%{_infodir}/avr,
    and include that path in your %files section.

b) %define _infodir %{_datadir}/info/avr

    or

    %define _infodir /usr/share/info/avr

-- 
Paul Heinlein <> heinlein@madboa.com <> www.madboa.com
